G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A, 29.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, 29, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as well as the Court’s general equity and parens patriae powers regarding the custody and welfare of minor children.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, 29, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as well as the Court’s general equity and parens patriae powers regarding the custody and welfare of minor children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify orders relative to the care, custody, and maintenance of minor children “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require,” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the best interests of the child are paramount in any custody or parenting-time determination.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: In assessing the best interests of the child, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s welfare, stability, safety, and the ability and availability of each parent to meet the child’s needs.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: The requested modification is narrowly tailored to address the specific material changes—namely, the Father’s 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. work schedule and the resulting safety and stability concerns—while maintaining his meaningful role in the children’s lives, consistent with G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, and cases such as Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. at 184–86, and Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the best interests of the child are paramount in any custody or parenting-time determination.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody matters the best interests of the child are the paramount concern, and interprets the governing statute in those terms. The court explains that the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language means removal must be in the best interests of the child and that those best interests “always remain the paramount concern,” directly supporting the proposition about Massachusetts custody and parenting-time determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the best interests of the child are paramount in any custody or parenting-time determination.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes the ‘best interests of the child’ as the governing standard in Massachusetts custody and visitation matters and labels those interests as the paramount concern. The court traces the historical development of the best-interests standard in Massachusetts law and reaffirms that custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a) must be made according to that standard, confirming that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody and parenting-time decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: A court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order where a material and substantial change in circumstances, not contemplated at the time of the prior judgment, affects the children’s welfare.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an appeal from an initial custody judgment and focuses on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not discuss the legal standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting-time order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances, nor does it reference changes not contemplated at the time of a prior judgment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.proposition: A court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order where a material and substantial change in circumstances, not contemplated at the time of the prior judgment, affects the children’s welfare.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Pierce v. Pierce concerns modification of alimony obligations following a payor’s voluntary retirement; it does not address legal standards for modifying custody or parenting-time orders. The key discussion is about the requirement of a material change of circumstances for alimony or child support generally, not about custody, and there is no analysis of parenting-time or custodial arrangements. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition regarding modification of custody or parenting time.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.”

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 681–82 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.proposition: A court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order where a material and substantial change in circumstances, not contemplated at the time of the prior judgment, affects the children’s welfare.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.support_reasoning: The opinion is about retroactive modification/credits against child support arrears under G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a), and the narrow equitable circumstances in which a court may grant an equitable credit. It does not set out or apply the standard for modifying custody or parenting-time orders based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. Any references to custody changes are solely in the context of evaluating equitable credits for child support, not as an articulation of the legal standard for modifying custody or parenting time.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation ‘in a manner other than as directed by the original order’ but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order.”

Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575, 580–81 (2007)
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.proposition: In assessing the best interests of the child, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s welfare, stability, safety, and the ability and availability of each parent to meet the child’s needs.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the relationship between parental fitness and the best interests standard in the context of guardianship and custody, not on articulating a specific multi-factor ‘best interests’ test involving welfare, stability, safety, and each parent’s ability and availability. While it mentions the child’s welfare and the effect of custody transfer on the child, it does not set out or apply the broader list of factors described in the proposition. Therefore it is not good authority for that specific articulated multi-factor standard.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “At the same time, the ‘best interests of the child’ is the touchstone of the analysis. … ‘The term [“unfitness”] is a standard by which we measure the circumstances within the family as they affect the child’s welfare.’ … At a minimum, the fitness of a particular parent cannot be judged without a consideration of that parent’s willingness and ability to care for the child, as well as the effect on a child of being placed in the custody of that parent.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: In assessing the best interests of the child, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s welfare, stability, safety, and the ability and availability of each parent to meet the child’s needs.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the dispositive question as determining the child’s best interests and discusses that this involves weighing stability and existing attachments against the adults’ abilities and track records in meeting the child’s special developmental needs. The court approves the trial judge’s consideration of Hugo’s need for a consistent, predictable, and stable environment, his welfare and safety, and the comparative ability and availability of each prospective custodian (foster mother vs. aunt) to address his special needs. This directly aligns with the proposition’s factors of welfare, stability, safety, and parental ability to meet the child’s needs.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt… The judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.proposition: In assessing the best interests of the child, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s welfare, stability, safety, and the ability and availability of each parent to meet the child’s needs.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for removing a child from a parent, focusing on parental unfitness, the presumption favoring parental custody, and the need for clear and convincing evidence that the child’s welfare would be endangered. It does not set out, in best‑interests terms, a multifactor test encompassing welfare, stability, safety, and the ability and availability of each parent to meet the child’s needs. Rather, it cautions against comparative fitness analyses and lifestyle-based judgments, so it does not affirm the specific best‑interests formulation in the proposition.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.relevant_excerpt: “‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’ … ‘Custody is not to be transferred from the natural parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. A comparison of the advantage the prospective custodian may offer to the child with those that may be offered by the natural parents is inappropriate.’”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.proposition: Where a parent’s work schedule or living arrangements substantially change so as to interfere with the existing parenting plan, this may constitute a material change justifying modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses relocation/removal in the context of joint physical custody and the best-interests standard, not modification of a parenting plan based on changes in a parent’s work schedule or living arrangements. The court does quote the ALI Principles that relocation can constitute a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not itself adopt or apply that rule as Massachusetts law, nor does it discuss work schedules or living- arrangement changes as a material change justifying modification. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the stated proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ...’
… ALI Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution, supra … supports the view that where ‘neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility,’ the effect of the relocation on the child is a ‘relevant factor[]’ in determining the child’s best interests.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Where a parent’s work schedule or living arrangements substantially change so as to interfere with the existing parenting plan, this may constitute a material change justifying modification.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss when a modification of custody is permissible, but the material change it identifies is the mother’s successful rehabilitation from substance abuse, not any change in a parent’s work schedule or living arrangements that interfered with an existing parenting plan. The case therefore does not stand for the specific proposition that a substantial change in work schedule or living arrangements may constitute a material change justifying modification; its discussion of material change is about parental fitness, not logistics or parenting-time interference.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment… In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”
